what is deprecation um so I think Twitter does a really good job or well did depending on your
persuasion a good job of defining deprecation because it's really clear
it's really simple it's really concise they say that deprecation is simply you
know something's no longer officially recommended if you find a bug or something don't exactly expect them to
fix it and they Define retirement as actually this feature is no longer accessible it's no longer viable to use
so it's really important to be clear on how you're going to Define deprecation versus retirement up front because if
you're not clear on how you're defining this phase of end of life for your services or your apis whatever it might
be you certainly can't expect end users or developers who are you know looking at your policies or working with your
services to be clear either so there's a lot of different terms out there for end of life you know you'll
see this referred to as sun setting decommissioning retiring um all this aside we're really looking
at two phases the first phase which we'll Define deprecation as something's no longer recommended for use uh you
know we're not going to be pouring new resources into it and the second phase of retirement which is you know this is
not possible to be used anymore it's been completely decommissioned so
um you know we have a sense of what we agree on for these definitions but why do we actually deprecate things in the
first place well any healthy service or future API
whatever it might be should obviously be evolving and you know expanding its capabilities over time and this is
exactly where deprecation comes in because you know the things that are in your software today could very well be
outdated irrelevant perhaps not even important to your product in the coming
years coming months um and we need a way to handle these older versions and offload the time the
resources the money that we're spending on maintaining things that may no longer be necessary
and so um you know now that we understand what deprecation is and why we do it
how do we actually achieve these goals well it all starts with trust the trust
of end users if it's a simple feature in your UI or the trust of developers if it's an API or a service that you're
offering externally this is the single biggest risk to identify upfront when deprecating a
future why you might ask maybe you don't ask but I'll tell you anyways and it's
because you're making a formal commitment down on paper so to speak that your apis or your future is going
to function exactly how you say it will or it'll stop functioning when you say it will and end users and developers may
actually rely on your services as the backbone of their own critical infrastructure you know in the example
up front you go to access the same piece of software you use every week but suddenly it's not working for you because of some dependent service this
is exactly what we want to avoid more succinctly trust is directly tied to
business impact for the people who are relying on your software so how do we avoid this risk
well we avoid this risk by avoiding each of these things so unclear timelines
that might be you know familiar to all of us hearing something like oh we'll get to that in Q3 or oh yeah we're aware
that we need to be ready to deprecate that but we'll talk about it in the new year this might look like a lack of internal
consensus so you know droves of meetings with no concrete takeaways no action
items not paying us you know not paying attention to shifting business priorities all sorts of things and this
might look like undocumented Behavior so you know product or engineering changes that were not communicated externally
so it's really important to call these out because a strategy for deprecating a future the
right way should really be thinking about maintaining this trust you've built with your end users and developers
throughout your product life cycle you know outside of future sets capabilities
the services you offer in an API or an SDK you know trust in a product is one
of the number one reasons that an individual will choose to work with your product over others
and this relies on us making you know clear actionable commitments to our end
users and anticipating their needs and how a deprecation is actually going to affect them
you know in their day-to-day work um it's really important to get this right on the first shot
because you really only get one shot if your strategy includes any of those you know ambiguities or you know bad ideas
that we were just talking about that's when end user end users or developers are going to start losing trust in your
product you know being hyper aware of these risks is actually in many ways just as
important as knowing what success looks like you know if your deprecation goes off without a hitch then you should hear
nothing about it you shouldn't hear from end users you shouldn't hear from developers there should be very little
noise because that means everything went you know according to plan but if your deprecation doesn't have a

people on social media you know people in your communities all it takes is one person with a bad experience to kind of
light that wildfire that can you know really start disintegrating that trust that you've built

more or less depending on your organization but you really also need one person dedicated to holding points on all of

so if you are a developer product this should be someone with an engineering background this should be like a

individuals in this working group be thinking about well these are what I'm going to call
the big three so these are you know three main components to be thinking
about up front as a working group internally and first is timelines so you
know from an engineering and product perspective when can we be certain or you know as certain as possible that
whatever feature or version is going to replace our existing one is actually going to be ready
and from there you know we can kind of start working backwards so okay if this is when we expect our V2 of this
existing feature to be ready when do we need to have communications ready when do we have to have a strategy you know
publicly posted and kind of so on and so forth from there
dependencies is the next thing so are there limitations or dependencies that could alter this kind of tentative
timeline that you have in your mind you could say okay we think we're going to be ready to retire this future this
endpoint in the spring of next year based off of what we've been talking about as a group but one of the things
that you're not thinking about that's a really difficult question to answer right because you don't know what
you don't know but you have to take time you have to account for time it's going to eat up some of your timeline so
there's going to be things like shifting business priorities there's going to be scrambling at the end to you know try
and have parity between future versions these are all sorts of things you should be thinking about as much as possible to
include in your timeline um just as kind of like a general you know safety buffer so to speak
and lastly messaging so this should be well informed acknowledge impact and
relay a really clear timeline or is as accurate as possible to customers
this of course should only come after these first two points have already been handled
so these are three big components to be thinking about internally but there are outside influences as well
that you should really be thinking about so like any good plan it's invaluable to
know how others before us have you know achieved the same challenge or tackle the same challenge

you know this is to say that there's no one-size-fits-all solution you're going

they appreciate it when you keep it real with them you know we can have all these plans but in reality at the end of the

you know it can be really difficult to achieve certain things like future parity and you may not always get it 100
it's much better to be transparent with your end users who may be developers and

retirement um deprecations usually most of the battle but nailing a retirement is also
extremely important as well you have to be looking at how services are performing in our case when we

if expectations differ from reality you may need to Pivot

it's a balance um it's a balance between developer Focus or end user focus and you know

all sorts of breaking changes so we release 2.0.0 in the new year and this brings me
right back to my original point of how deprecation is so in you know involved
in this versioning strategy because we now need a way to handle this version 1.0.0 which has become way less relevant
to us now that we offer this V 2.0.0 and this is really actually an example
of some basic semantic versioning so I'm sure a lot of us are probably quite familiar with what semantic
versioning looks like but in case you aren't we'll just do a quick crash course here and I'll call out you know
kind of the Three core facets of semantic versioning so first you have a major version
reserved for breaking changes that's our 2.0.0 in the hypothetical situation we were just talking about
then you have a minor version so that is backwards compatible typically for future enhancements maybe like optional
parameters in an API nothing that's going to break anything but usually for the better
and then we have our patch version so that would be uh like 1.1.2 or something and that is to bring
a bug or something back to its original intended Behavior so you are fixing
something but it's technically backwards compatible because it wasn't supposed to behave in that way in the first place
so this is kind of just very high level semantic versioning for us but I bring it up because this is a very popular
standard for versioning and versioning itself is such an important part of being able to deprecate something the
right way when the time comes all right so now that we know how this
is all related let's take a closer look at what a good versioning policy might look like
and for this I'll use an example that I think we're all probably familiar with which is GitHub

so what makes it so good well there's a few different things but first
their versioning follows a very easy to understand standard which is that it is
directly tied to the date when that version was released it's very hard to mix that up second they promised that breaking
changes will never be introduced in a minor version or in the case of GitHub it's a little bit different but that
might include kind of their minor and Patch versions in every you know subsequent version that they give but
this is just for an easy easy example for us third they provide a clear list of how
